facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 669 of 1965 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION CIVIL APPEAL No. 669 OF 1965.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated October 5, 1961 of Madhya Pradesh High Court in M.P. No. 153 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated October 5, 1961 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in M. P. No. 153 of 1961.

facts.text: Notice issued by Divisional Forest Officer, Jabalpur Division for auction of various forest contracts in July 1959.

anchor.surface_text: The brief facts necessary for present purposes are these. A notice was issued by the Divisional Forest Officer, Jabalpur Division for auction of various contracts in that division in July 1959.

facts.text: Auction conditions required bidder to sign sale notice and deposit Rs. 500/- earnest money per contract.

anchor.surface_text: The conditions of the auction specified inter alia a that no person would be allowed to bid for any forest contract at the auction unless he had signed the sale notice in token of his agreement to abide by the conditions thereof and deposited a sum of Rs. 500/- as earnest money in respect of each forest contract before bidding therefor

facts.text: Divisional Forest Officer reserved power to accept highest or any bid without reason.

anchor.surface_text: b that the Divisional Forest Officer reserved to himself the power without assigning any reason to accept the highest or any bid,

facts.text: Contract consideration over Rs. 3,000/- payable in four equal instalments, first immediately at auction close.

anchor.surface_text: c that the consideration due under a contract was to be payable where it exceeded Rs. 3,000/-, in four equal instalments, the first instalment being payable immediately at the close of the auction

facts.text: Successful bidder to sign bid-sheet immediately at auction close.

anchor.surface_text: d that the successful bidder had to sign immediately at the close of the auction the bid-sheet for the contract knocked down in his favour

facts.text: Appellant bid for two contracts at auction and had highest bids.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant bid for two contracts at the auction and his were the highest bids.

facts.text: Auction amount exceeded Divisional Forest Officer's sanction power, referred to Chief Conservator of Forests.

anchor.surface_text: As the amount of the contract money was more than what the Divisional Forest Officer could accept, the matter was referred to the Chief Conservator of Forests who had the necessary authority to accept the bids.

facts.text: After auction close, appellant signed contract form and surety signed security bond.

anchor.surface_text: After the close of the auction the appellant had signed the contract form and a surety signed the security bond as required.

facts.text: Appellant raised dispute on marking of trees per material notified at auction time.

anchor.surface_text: Before however the Chief Conservator of Forests could accept the contract, the appellant raised a dispute as to the marking of the trees according to the material notified at the time of the auction.

facts.text: Appellant refused to complete contract or pay first instalment due to unresolved dispute.

anchor.surface_text: As that dispute was not settled to the satisfaction of the appellant he refused to complete the contract or to pay the first instalment in respect thereof.

facts.text: Divisional Forest Officer issued notice to appellant on July 29, 1959 to complete formalities within a week or face re-auction and forfeiture.

anchor.surface_text: Eventually the Divisional Forest Officer gave notice to the appellant on July 29, 1959 that if he did not complete the formalities within a week, action would be taken under the conditions of auction to re-auction the contract and if there was any deficiency it would be recovered from him and the earnest money would be forfeited.

facts.text: Appellant did not pay first instalment.

anchor.surface_text: He did not however pay the first instalment due

facts.text: On November 25, 1959, informed appellant that sale of two contracts auctioned July 20, 1959 cancelled by Chief Conservator, earnest forfeited, to be re-auctioned at his risk.

anchor.surface_text: and ultimately on November 25, 1959 he was informed that the sale of the two contracts sold in the auction held on July 20, 1959 in his favour had been cancelled by the Chief Conservator of Forests and the amount of earnest money had been forfeited. He was also informed that the two contracts would be re-auctioned at his risk.

facts.text: Contracts re-auctioned in January 1960 with deficiency of Rs. 51,500/- together.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the contracts were re-auctioned in January 1960. At the re-auction there was a deficiency in the two contracts together of Rs. 51,500/-

facts.text: Appellant asked to pay deficiency amount Rs. 51,500/- to Divisional Forest Officer, failed to do so.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was therefore asked to send this amount to the Divisional Forest Officer. When he failed to do so,

facts.text: Divisional Forest Officer wrote to Tehsildar Jabalpur to recover amount as arrears of land revenue.

anchor.surface_text: a letter was addressed to the Tehsildar Jabalpur by the Divisional Forest Officer for recovering this amount as arrears of land revenue under the conditions of auction.

facts.text: Appellant filed writ petition claiming no recovery under s.82 Indian Forest Act or rules 28,29 MP Forest Contract Rules as no contract signed or completed.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the appellant filed a writ petition out of which the present appeal has arisen. The case of the appellant was that the claim of the respondent-State for recovery of the deficiency on re-sale was not covered by either s. 82 of the Indian Forest Act, No. 16 of 1927 or rules 28 and 29 of the Madhya Pradesh Forest Contract Rules or under any other provision of the law, and the amount therefore could not be recovered as arrears of land revenue as the contract was not signed or completed by him.

facts.text: State contested that recovery possible as arrears under s.82 Indian Forest Act read with rr.28,29 and auction conditions accepted by appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The State contested the case and contended that recovery of the amount could be effected as arrears of land revenue under s. 82 of the Indian Act read with rr. 28 and 29 of the Forest Contract Rules in view of the conditions of auction, which the appellant had accepted.

facts.text: Full Bench of High Court held rr.28,29 not apply as no written contract executed by Chief Conservator.

anchor.surface_text: The Full Bench seems to have held that rr. 28 and 29 of the Forest Contract Rules did not apply to the case as they dealt with breaches arising after the contract in writing had been executed. In this case the admitted position was that the contract in writing had never been signed by the Chief Conservator of Forests

facts.text: High Court held implied contract from auction conditions, not hit by Art.299 Constitution, recoverable under s.155(b) MP Land Revenue Code as arrears.

anchor.surface_text: the Full Bench went on to hold that this was a case of an implied contract resulting from the appellants accepting the conditions of auction and that such an implied contract was not hit by Art. 299 of the Constitution as that applied plainly to contracts which are required to be reduced to writing and an implied contract in its very nature was not such a contract. Finally the full Bench held that s. 155 b of the Madhya Pradesh Land Revenue Code, 1959, applied to this case of implied contract and the amount could be recovered thereunder as arrears of land revenue.

facts.text: High Court dismissed writ petition.

anchor.surface_text: On this view the petition was dismissed.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave after High Court refused certificate.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court having refused to grant a certificate, the appellant applied for and obtained special leave from this Court

facts.text: No contract as required by Art.299(1) Constitution ever existed between appellant and Government.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case it is not in dispute that there never was a contract as required by Art. 299 1 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Supreme Court held no implied contract possible due to Art.299(1), s.155(b) MP Land Revenue Code not applicable for recovery.

anchor.surface_text: The view therefore taken by the High Court that this amount could be recovered under s. 155 b is not correct.

facts.text: Supreme Court remands to High Court to investigate if recoverable under other provisions like s.82,85 Indian Forest Act or rules.

anchor.surface_text: We however remand the matter to the High Court for determining after hearing both parties whether there is any other provision of law or rules which would permit the recovery of this amount in view of the conditions of auction.

concepts.interpretation: Rules out all implied contracts between government and another person

issues.text: whether the High Court's view that Art. 299 of the Constitution does not hit an implied contract and therefore the amount could be recovered under s. 155 b of the Madhya Pradesh Land Revenue Code is correct

anchor.surface_text: Two questions arise for decision in this appeal. The first is whether the High Courts view that Art. 299 of the Constitution ,does number hit an implied companytract and therefore the amount companyld be recovered under s. 155 b  of the Madhya Pradesh Land Revenue Code is companyrect.

issues.text: if that view is not correct, whether the amount can be recovered as arrears of land revenue under any other provision of law

anchor.surface_text: The second is that if that view is number companyrect, whether the amount can be recovered as arrears of land revenue under any other provision of law. It may be mentioned that Art. 299 1  of the Constitution with which we are companycerned is practically in the same terms as S. 175 3  of the Government of India Act, 1935.

issues.text: whether rr. 28 and 29 of the Forest Contract Rules apply to the case as they dealt with breaches arising after the contract in writing had been executed

anchor.surface_text: The Full, Bench seems to have held that rr. 28 and 29 of the Forest Contract Rules did number apply to the case as they dealt with breaches arising after the companytract in writing had been executed. In this case the admitted position was that the companytract in writing had never been signed by the Chief Conservator of Forests

issues.text: whether the liability arising under the conditions of auction could be enforced and the deficiency on re-auction recovered as arrears of land revenue even without the execution of a valid contract in writing

anchor.surface_text: therefore the question which fell to be companysidered, according to the Full Bench, was whether the liability arising under the companyditions of auction companyld be enforced and the deficiency on re-auction recover as arrears of land revenue even without the execution of a valid companytract in writing.

arguments.claim: Claim of respondent-State for recovery of deficiency on re-sale not covered by s.82 Indian Forest Act or rules 28,29 MP Forest Contract Rules or any other provision of law; cannot be recovered as arrears of land revenue as contract not signed or completed

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the appellant filed a writ petition out of which the present appeal has arisen. The case of the appellant was that the claim of the respondent-State for recovery of the deficiency on re-sale was not covered by either s. 82 of the Indian Forest Act, No. 16 of 1927 or rules 28 and 29 of the Madhya Pradesh Forest Contract Rules or under any other provision of the law, and the amount therefore could not be recovered as arrears of land revenue as the contract was not signed or completed by him.

arguments.court_reasoning: Agrees no written contract under Art.299(1), rr.28/29 apply post-execution only, s.155(b) inapplicable to implied contracts; remands for check on s.82/85 IFA etc.

arguments.claim: Recovery of amount can be effected as arrears of land revenue under s.82 Indian Forest Act read with rr.28,29 Forest Contract Rules in view of conditions of auction accepted by appellant

anchor.surface_text: The State contested the case and contended that recovery of the amount could be effected as arrears of land revenue under s. 82 of the Indian Act read with rr. 28 and 29 of the Forest Contract Rules in view of the conditions of auction, which the appellant had accepted.

arguments.court_reasoning: rr.28/29 deal with breaches after written contract executed; no such contract signed by Chief Conservator

arguments.claim: rr.28 and 29 Forest Contract Rules do not apply as they deal with breaches arising after contract in writing executed; contract never signed by Chief Conservator

anchor.surface_text: The Full Bench seems to have held that rr. 28 and 29 of the Forest Contract Rules did not apply to the case as they dealt with breaches arising after the contract in writing had been executed. In this case the admitted position was that the contract in writing had never been signed by the Chief Conservator of Forests

arguments.court_reasoning: The view of the High Court that rr. 28 and 29 ... appears to be correct

arguments.claim: Implied contract results from appellant accepting conditions of auction; not hit by Art.299 Constitution as applies to contracts required to be reduced to writing; implied contract not such

anchor.surface_text: the Full Bench went on to hold that this was a case of an implied contract resulting from the appellants accepting the conditions of auction and that such an implied contract was not hit by Art. 299 of the Constitution as that applied plainly to contracts which are required to be reduced to writing and an implied contract in its very nature was not such a contract.

arguments.court_reasoning: Art.299(1) rules out all implied contracts; would make provision useless if allowed

arguments.claim: s.155(b) Madhya Pradesh Land Revenue Code applies to implied contract; amount recoverable thereunder as arrears of land revenue

anchor.surface_text: Finally the full Bench held that s. 155 b of the Madhya Pradesh Land Revenue Code, 1959, applied to this case of implied contract and the amount could be recovered thereunder as arrears of land revenue.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: s of land revenue. That question has still to be investigated and it would be for the State to show whether the amount can be recovered under any prov

arguments.court_reasoning: No implied contract possible under Art.299(1); word 'contract' in s.155(b) cannot include implied

arguments.claim: No implied contract possible between Government and another person in view of Art.299(1); would make Art.299(1) useless
No contract as required by Art.299(1) ever existed; bidding, signing bid-sheet etc. do not satisfy Art.299(1)

anchor.surface_text: In the present case it is not in dispute that there never was a contract as required by Art. 299 1 of the Constitution. Nor can the fact that the appellant bid at the auction and signed the bid-sheet at the close thereof or signed the declaration necessary before he could bid at the auction amount to a contract between him and the Government satisfying all the conditions of Art. 299 1 .

arguments.claim: Amount can be recovered under s.82 or s.85 Indian Forest Act

court_response_anchor.surface_text: rules which would permit the recovery of this amount in view of the companyditions of auction.

arguments.court_reasoning: Not investigated by High Court; remanded for determination

arguments.claim: Art.299(1) provisions mandatory like s.175(3) GOIA; requires expressed by Governor, writing, authorized execution; no implied contracts

anchor.surface_text: What was said in these cases with respect to S. 175 3 of the Government of India Act, 1935, applies with equal force to Art. 299 1 of the Constitution.

arguments.claim: Claim of State for recovery not covered under any other provision of law to make recoverable as arrears

court_response_anchor.surface_text: rules which would permit the recovery of this amount in view of the companyditions of auction.

arguments.court_reasoning: Requires investigation; remanded to High Court

holdings.text: What was said in these cases with respect to S. 175 3 of the Government of India Act, 1935, applies with equal force to Art. 299 1 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: What was said in these cases with respect to S. 175 3 of the Government of India Act, 1935, applies with equal force to Art. 299 1 of the Constitution. Two consequences follow from these decisions.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedent on mandatory nature of s.175(3) GOIA directly applies to identical Art.299(1).

holdings.text: in view of Art. 299 1 there can be no implied contract between the Government and another person, the reason being that if such implied contracts between the Government and another person were allowed, they would in effect make Art. 299 1 useless,
holdings.reasoning_summary: Art.299(1) mandatory; allowing implied contracts would render it otiose, per precedents.

holdings.text: there never was a contract as required by Art. 299 1 of the Constitution. Nor can the fact that the appellant bid at the auction and signed the bid-sheet at the close thereof or signed the declaration necessary before he could bid at the auction amount to a contract between him and the Government satisfying all the conditions of Art. 299 1 .

anchor.surface_text: In the present case it is not in dispute that there never was a contract as required by Art. 299 1 of the Constitution. Nor can the fact that the appellant bid at the auction and signed the bid-sheet at the close thereof or signed the declaration necessary before he could bid at the auction amount to a contract between him and the Government satisfying all the conditions of Art. 299 1 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Auction bidding and signing do not meet express, written, authorized requirements of Art.299(1).

holdings.text: The view therefore taken by the High Court that this amount could be recovered under s. 155 b is not correct.

anchor.surface_text: The view therefore taken by the High Court that this amount could be recovered under s. 155 b is not correct. This brings us to the second question, namely, whether the amount can be recovered under any other provision of law as arrears of land revenue.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No valid/implied contract exists under Art.299(1), so 'contract' in s.155(b) cannot include implied ones for recovery as arrears.

holdings.text: The view of the High Court that rr. 28 and 29 of the Forest Contract Rules apply after a contract in writing has been executed appears to be correct.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Rules apply to breaches post written contract execution; none occurred here.

holdings.text: We therefore allow the appeal and hold that s. 155 b of the Madhya Pradesh Land Revenue Code does not assist the State in realising this amount as arrears of land revenue.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Overrules High Court; no recovery under s.155(b) due to absence of valid contract.

holdings.text: We however remand the matter to the High Court for determining after hearing both parties whether there is any other provision of law or rules which would permit the recovery of this amount in view of the conditions of auction.

anchor.surface_text: We however remand the matter to the High Court for determining after hearing both parties whether there is any other provision of law or rules which would permit the recovery of this amount in view of the conditions of auction.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court did not investigate s.82/85 IFA or other rules; requires further determination.

precedents.citation: The State of Bihar Messrs. Karam Chand Thapar 1

anchor.surface_text: The State of Bihar Messrs. Karam Chand Thapar 1 It held that under S. 175 3 , three companyditions had to be satisfied before a binding companytract against the Government companyld arise.

precedents.case_name: The State of Bihar v. Messrs. Karam Chand Thapar
precedents.cited_proposition: Under S. 175(3) of the Government of India Act, 1935, three conditions must be satisfied for a binding contract with Government: (i) expressed to be made by Governor; (ii) executed in writing; (iii) executed by authorised persons in authorised manner. No particular mode for conferring authority required if ad hoc.
precedents.cited_holding: S. 175(3) did not prescribe any particular mode in which the authority must be conferred.

precedents.citation: Seth Bikhrai Jaipuiria v. Union of India 2

anchor.surface_text: Seth Bikhrai Jaipuiria v. Union of India 2 It was again emphasised that S. 175 3 of the Government of India Act, 1935, required that a companytract, if it was to bind the Government, had a to be expressed to be made by the Governor or Governor General

precedents.case_name: Seth Bikhrai Jaipuria v. Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: S. 175(3) mandatory; contract to bind Government must be expressed to be made by Governor, executed on his behalf by duly authorised officer.

precedents.citation: State of West Bengal v. Messrs. B. K. Mondal and Sons 3

anchor.surface_text: State of West Bengal v. Messrs. B. K. Mondal and Sons 3 It was held that the provisions contained in S. 175 3 were mandatory. The intention of Parliament in enacting the provision was that the State should number be burdened with liability based on unauthorised companytracts.

precedents.case_name: State of West Bengal v. Messrs. B. K. Mondal and Sons
precedents.cited_proposition: Provisions of S. 175(3) are mandatory to prevent liability for unauthorised contracts; 'shall' is obligatory.
precedents.cited_holding: S. 70 of Contract Act applicable against Government if acted lawfully, non-gratuitously, and benefit enjoyed.

precedents.citation: Chaturbhuj Vithaldas Jasani v. Moreshwar Prashram 4

anchor.surface_text: Chaturbhuj Vithaldas Jasani v. Moreshwar Prashram 4 was explained in that decision and it was held that it should be companyfined to its own facts in the companytext of the Representation of the People Act.

precedents.case_name: Chaturbhuj Vithaldas Jasani v. Moreshwar Prashram
precedents.cited_proposition: Explained and confined to its own facts in the context of the Representation of the People Act.

precedents.citation: Union of India v. A. L. Rallia Ram, 5

anchor.surface_text: Union of India v. A. L. Rallia Ram, 5 and it was held that so long as all the requirements of S. 175 3 of the Government of India Act were fulfilled and were clear from the companyrespondence, S. 175 3 did number necessarily require the execution of any formal document.

precedents.case_name: Union of India v. A. L. Rallia Ram
precedents.cited_proposition: Requirements of S. 175(3) need not require execution of formal document if fulfilled and clear from correspondence.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case it is not in dispute that there never was a contract as required by Art. 299 1 of the Constitution. Nor can the fact that the appellant bid at the auction and signed the bid-sheet at the close thereof or signed the declaration necessary before he could bid at the auction amount to a contract between him and the Government satisfying all the conditions of Art. 299 1 .
We therefore allow the appeal and hold that s. 155 b of the Madhya Pradesh Land Revenue Code does number assist the State in realising this amount as arrears of land revenue. We h
